quiz.question: On average, how much bigger are homes today than they were in the 70s?
quiz.feedback: In the 1970s the average home was 1,600 sqaure feet. Homes today average 2,400 square feet.

quiz.question: According to the Department of Energy (DOE), how many gallons of water does the average family use in a day?
quiz.feedback: The average family uses about 60 gallons of water each day.

quiz.question: The DOE estimates a family of 4 can send how many gallons down the drain while waiting for hot qater to arrive.
quiz.feedback: The average family of 4 wastes about 12,000 gallons of water per year waiting for hot water.

quiz.question: In the 1970's, the pipe run to the farthest fixture averaged 30 feet.  In homes built today the distance averages:
quiz.feedback: The distance from the water heater to the fathest fixture has almost tripled, from 30 feet in the 70's to 80-90 feet today.

quiz.question: According to DOE estimates, approximately how much of the money spent on hot water is wasted?
quiz.feedback: Leaving fixtures open while waiting for hot water to arrive can waste as much as 1/3 of every domestic hot water dollar.

quiz.question: A recirculation system with a central manifold and hot and cold lines going out to the fixtures is called:
quiz.feedback: A Home run system configuration has a central manifold with hot and cold lines going to the fixtures.

quiz.question: Half-loop recirculation is more efficient than full-loop recirculation.
quiz.feedback: Half-loop configurations save energy by using an aquastat to shut the pump off as soon as there's hot water at the farthest fixture.

quiz.question: Aquastats can be installed at the water heater or the farthest fixture.
quiz.feedback: Aquastats should be installed just before or just after the farthest fixture.

quiz.question: Timer based recirculation is a good choice for tankless systems.
quiz.feedback: If the timer tells the tankless water heater to run when you actually don't need hot water, you'll end up short-cycling the heater and shorten its life.

quiz.question: The digital version of Taco's Plumb n' Plug can handle how many events each day?
quiz.feedback: The Plumb n' Plug with the digital timer can handle up to 7 separate events a day, for a total of 49 events a week.

quiz.question: The SmartPlus can be used with or without a dedicated recirculation line.
quiz.feedback: The SmartPlus has to have a recirculation line.  So it's not an option for retrofits, unless you have a relatively easy way to install one.

quiz.question: Using the sensor with the SmartPlus will improve its performance, but insatllation is optional.
quiz.feedback: For the SmartPlus to function properly, you must use the sensor.

quiz.question: The SmartPlus cycles at theis rate:
quiz.feedback: The SmartPlus cycles at a rate of 2-1/2 minutes on and 10 minutes off.

quiz.question: Which of the following is NOT a hot water event?
quiz.feedback: A quick hand washing would not last long enough for the SmartPlus to recognize it as a hot water event.

quiz.question: The TacoGenie can be used with or without a dedicated return line.
quiz.feedback: The TacoGenie is capable of using the cold water return line as a return, as well as a dedicated line.

quiz.question: The TacoGenie cannot be used with tankless systems.
quiz.feedback: The TacoGenie has the versatility to handle both traditional and tankless DHW systems.

quiz.question: How long is the lockout period on the TacoGenie?
quiz.feedback: There is an 8 minute lockout period before the TacoGenie can be reactivated.

quiz.question: The TacoGenie will not operate if the temperature of the water on the inlet side reaches:
quiz.feedback: The TacoGenie has a fail-safe feature that will prevent it from operating if the temperature on the inlet side ever reaches 100 degrees.
